intro: Draba paysonii var. treleasei, commonly known as the Payson's whitlow grass, is a low-growing perennial herb native to the western United States. It typically thrives in rocky, alpine, and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers during the spring and early summer. Its leaves are basal, linear, and often covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. This variety is part of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its four-petaled flowers and seed pods that split open to release seeds.
